00:00:11:100000.Speaker: Leonard
00:00:11:100000.Dialogue: I think it upsets Sheldon when you play with the food.

00:00:13:220000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:00:13:220000.Dialogue: No. It upsets Sheldon when she willy-nilly takes it from the containers without regard for its equitable distribution. This is essentially why you have famine in India.

00:00:26:060000.Speaker: Penny
00:00:26:060000.Dialogue: You want me to put it back?

00:00:30:150000.Speaker: Leonard
00:00:30:150000.Dialogue: It upsets Sheldon when you play with the Sheldon.

00:00:39:000000.Speaker: Howard
00:00:39:000000.Dialogue: Raj, Sheldon, I want you to meet my girlfriend Bernadette.

00:00:46:100000.Speaker: Howard
00:00:46:100000.Dialogue: Bernadette, say fo'shizzle to my nerdizzles.

00:00:49:160000.Speaker: Bernadette
00:00:49:160000.Dialogue: I don't think I can. I don't have Howard's street cred.

00:00:57:010000.Speaker: Howard
00:00:57:010000.Dialogue: I told my girlfriend Bernadette she could join us for dinner.

00:01:00:220000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:01:00:220000.Dialogue: Wa- no, that's a false equivalency. More does not equal merry. If there were 2,000 people in this apartment right now, would we be celebrating? No, we'd be suffocating.

00:01:10:190000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:01:10:190000.Dialogue: Don't "Sheldon" me. We ordered for five people, not six.

00:01:13:040000.Speaker: Penny
00:01:13:040000.Dialogue: Oh, come on, it's fine. We'll just put it all on the table, you know, family style.

00:01:17:030000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:01:17:030000.Dialogue: Oh, sure. And while we're at it, why don't we put our hands behind our backs, have an old-fashioned eating contest?

00:01:21:180000.Speaker: Leonard
00:01:21:180000.Dialogue: Relax, it'll be fine. Sit down, you guys.

00:01:29:120000.Speaker: Penny
00:01:29:120000.Dialogue: Oh, yeah, you can't sit there.

00:01:37:220000.Speaker: Penny
00:01:37:220000.Dialogue: No, no, no- you see, in the winter, that seat is close enough to the radiator so that he's warm, yet not so close that he sweats. In the summer, it's directly in the path of a cross-breeze created by opening windows there and there. It faces the television at an angle that isn't direct, so he can still talk to everybody, yet not so wide that the picture looks distorted.

00:01:57:190000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:01:57:190000.Dialogue: Perhaps there's hope for you after all.

00:02:29:150000.Speaker: Penny
00:02:29:150000.Dialogue: Oh, thanks. They are cute, aren't they?

00:02:33:180000.Speaker: Bernadette
00:02:33:180000.Dialogue: I've been meaning to go over there.

00:02:38:090000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:02:38:090000.Dialogue: My mother was right. Hell is real.

00:02:42:080000.Speaker: Howard
00:02:42:080000.Dialogue: Come on, Sheldon. Let the womenfolk chat.

00:02:57:070000.Speaker: Bernadette
00:02:57:070000.Dialogue: Don't take him too seriously. A lot of what he says is intended as humor.

00:03:02:190000.Speaker: Penny
00:03:02:190000.Dialogue: Yeah, well, I don't think it's very funny.

00:03:05:010000.Speaker: Bernadette
00:03:05:010000.Dialogue: Me neither, but he just lights up when I laugh.

00:03:15:150000.Speaker: Bernadette
00:03:15:150000.Dialogue: So, Leonard, Howard says you're working on fundamental tests of quantum mechanics.

00:03:19:060000.Speaker: Leonard
00:03:19:060000.Dialogue: I am. Are you interested in physics?

00:03:21:190000.Speaker: Bernadette
00:03:21:190000.Dialogue: Oh, I find it fascinating. If I hadn't gone into microbiology, I probably would have gone into physics. Or ice dancing.

00:03:30:060000.Speaker: Leonard
00:03:30:060000.Dialogue: Actually, my tests of the Aharonov-Bohm quantum interference effect have reached an interesting point. Right now, we're testing the phase shift due to an electric potential.

00:03:38:230000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:03:38:230000.Dialogue: SHELDON Yes. Leonard's work is nearly as amazing as third graders growing lima beans in wet paper towels.

00:03:47:060000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:03:47:060000.Dialogue: While I appreciate the "Oh, snap," I'm uncomfortable having your moist breath in my ear.

00:03:55:140000.Speaker: Bernadette
00:03:55:140000.Dialogue: Are you going to try to set up the voltages using tunnel junctions?

00:04:00:190000.Speaker: Leonard
00:04:00:190000.Dialogue: Yes, I am. You want to see a simulation on my laptop?

00:04:04:000000.Speaker: Bernadette
00:04:04:000000.Dialogue: Oh, yeah, show me. In microbiology, the most exciting thing I get to work with is yeast.

00:04:31:150000.Scene: The apartment. Sheldon and Raj are playing a racing game on the Wii.
00:04:31:150000.Speaker: Raj
00:04:31:150000.Dialogue: Ha! Eat my dust, racially stereotypical plumber.

00:04:37:210000.Scene: The apartment. Sheldon and Raj are playing a racing game on the Wii.
00:04:37:210000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:04:37:210000.Dialogue: That's not fair. I got stuck behind a tree.

00:04:41:150000.Scene: The apartment. Sheldon and Raj are playing a racing game on the Wii.
00:04:41:150000.Speaker: Raj
00:04:41:150000.Dialogue: And a cow and a penguin.

00:04:43:130000.Scene: The apartment. Sheldon and Raj are playing a racing game on the Wii.
00:04:43:130000.Speaker: Raj
00:04:43:130000.Dialogue: Face it, dude, whether it's a real car or a virtual cartoon car, you can't drive.

00:04:50:060000.Scene: The apartment. Sheldon and Raj are playing a racing game on the Wii.
00:04:50:060000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:04:50:060000.Dialogue: Just need a little more practice.

00:04:52:010000.Scene: The apartment. Sheldon and Raj are playing a racing game on the Wii.
00:04:52:010000.Speaker: Raj
00:04:52:010000.Dialogue: What you need is cheat codes, motor skills and a magic genie who grants wishes to little boys who suck at Mario Kart.

00:05:01:010000.Scene: The apartment. Sheldon and Raj are playing a racing game on the Wii.
00:05:01:010000.Speaker: Penny
00:05:01:010000.Dialogue: Hey, Sheldon, can I talk to you for a second?

00:05:04:010000.Scene: The apartment. Sheldon and Raj are playing a racing game on the Wii.
00:05:04:010000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:05:04:010000.Dialogue: It's not about shoes, is it? I don't think I could go through that again.

00:05:08:210000.Scene: The apartment. Sheldon and Raj are playing a racing game on the Wii.
00:05:08:210000.Speaker: Penny

00:05:10:090000.Scene: The apartment. Sheldon and Raj are playing a racing game on the Wii.
00:05:10:090000.Speaker: Sheldon

00:05:11:150000.Scene: The apartment. Sheldon and Raj are playing a racing game on the Wii.
00:05:11:150000.Speaker: Penny
00:05:11:150000.Dialogue: Um, actually, can we do it in private?

00:05:14:090000.Scene: The apartment. Sheldon and Raj are playing a racing game on the Wii.
00:05:14:090000.Speaker: Sheldon

00:05:19:090000.Scene: The apartment. Sheldon and Raj are playing a racing game on the Wii.
00:05:19:090000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:05:19:090000.Dialogue: I agree, it's rude, but she asked for privacy.

00:05:23:040000.Scene: The apartment. Sheldon and Raj are playing a racing game on the Wii.
00:05:23:040000.Speaker: Penny
00:05:23:040000.Dialogue: Thanks, Raj. Okay, so here's the thing: I was wondering if you could maybe teach me a little physics?

00:05:30:180000.Scene: The apartment. Sheldon and Raj are playing a racing game on the Wii.
00:05:30:180000.Speaker: Sheldon

00:05:34:180000.Scene: The apartment. Sheldon and Raj are playing a racing game on the Wii.
00:05:34:180000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:05:34:180000.Dialogue: There's no such thing. Physics encompasses the entire universe, from quantum particles to supernovas, from spinning electrons to spinning galaxies.

00:05:43:180000.Scene: The apartment. Sheldon and Raj are playing a racing game on the Wii.
00:05:43:180000.Speaker: Penny
00:05:43:180000.Dialogue: Yeah, okay, cool. I don't need the PBS special. I just want to know enough so I can talk to Leonard about his job. You know, like Bernadette does.

00:05:50:220000.Scene: The apartment. Sheldon and Raj are playing a racing game on the Wii.
00:05:50:220000.Speaker: Sheldon

00:05:52:130000.Scene: The apartment. Sheldon and Raj are playing a racing game on the Wii.
00:05:52:130000.Speaker: Penny

00:05:54:010000.Scene: The apartment. Sheldon and Raj are playing a racing game on the Wii.
00:05:54:010000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:05:54:010000.Dialogue: Can't you surprise him in some other way? For example, I'm sure he'd be delightfully taken aback if you cleaned your apartment.

00:06:00:100000.Scene: The apartment. Sheldon and Raj are playing a racing game on the Wii.
00:06:00:100000.Speaker: Penny
00:06:00:100000.Dialogue: Come on, Sheldon, this is important to me.

00:06:03:010000.Scene: The apartment. Sheldon and Raj are playing a racing game on the Wii.
00:06:03:010000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:06:03:010000.Dialogue: Penny, this would be a massive undertaking, and my time is both limited and valuable.

00:06:08:100000.Scene: The apartment. Sheldon and Raj are playing a racing game on the Wii.
00:06:08:100000.Speaker: Penny
00:06:08:100000.Dialogue: You're sitting here playing video games all day.

00:06:11:220000.Scene: The apartment. Sheldon and Raj are playing a racing game on the Wii.
00:06:11:220000.Speaker: Sheldon

00:06:13:000000.Scene: The apartment. Sheldon and Raj are playing a racing game on the Wii.

00:06:14:180000.Scene: The apartment. Sheldon and Raj are playing a racing game on the Wii.
00:06:14:180000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:06:14:180000.Dialogue: What sort of foundation do you have? Did you take any science classes in school?

00:06:19:070000.Scene: The apartment. Sheldon and Raj are playing a racing game on the Wii.
00:06:19:070000.Speaker: Penny
00:06:19:070000.Dialogue: Sure. I did the one with the frogs.

00:06:24:100000.Scene: The apartment. Sheldon and Raj are playing a racing game on the Wii.
00:06:24:100000.Speaker: Sheldon

00:06:27:070000.Scene: The apartment. Sheldon and Raj are playing a racing game on the Wii.
00:06:27:070000.Speaker: Penny
00:06:27:070000.Dialogue: Yeah, actually, it was pretty cool. A lot of the girls threw up, but I gutted that thing like a deer.

00:06:31:190000.Scene: The apartment. Sheldon and Raj are playing a racing game on the Wii.
00:06:31:190000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:06:31:190000.Dialogue: I'm sorry, Penny. I don't think so.

00:06:34:180000.Scene: The apartment. Sheldon and Raj are playing a racing game on the Wii.
00:06:34:180000.Speaker: Penny
00:06:34:180000.Dialogue: Oh, come on! A smart guy like you, it'll be a challenge. You can make it like an experiment.

00:06:41:060000.Scene: The apartment. Sheldon and Raj are playing a racing game on the Wii.
00:06:41:060000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:06:41:060000.Dialogue: Interesting. I suppose if someone could teach sign language to KoKo the gorilla... I could teach you some rudimentary physics.

00:06:51:080000.Scene: The apartment. Sheldon and Raj are playing a racing game on the Wii.
00:06:51:080000.Speaker: Penny
00:06:51:080000.Dialogue: Great! It's a little insulting, but great. I'll be KoKo.

00:06:55:130000.Scene: The apartment. Sheldon and Raj are playing a racing game on the Wii.
00:06:55:130000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:06:55:130000.Dialogue: Not likely. KoKo learned to understand over 2,000 words, not one of which had anything to do with shoes.

00:07:03:170000.Speaker: Howard
00:07:03:170000.Dialogue: Hey, fellas. This is my girlfriend Bernadette. My girlfriend Bernadette.

00:07:18:140000.Speaker: Howard
00:07:18:140000.Dialogue: Thought I'd give the little woman a tour of the old salt mines. He doesn't mean salt mines.

00:07:33:140000.Speaker: Leonard
00:07:33:140000.Dialogue: Ah, terrific. We're getting the electron accelerator set up. We should be ready to go day after tomorrow.

00:07:38:060000.Speaker: Bernadette
00:07:38:060000.Dialogue: Boy, I'd love to see that.

00:07:41:090000.Speaker: Bernadette
00:07:41:090000.Dialogue: Really? Oh, that'd be great. How exciting is that?

00:07:58:170000.Speaker: Bernadette
00:07:58:170000.Dialogue: This isn't non-fat yogurt. This is fatty fat fat. Excuse me.

00:08:05:050000.Speaker: Howard
00:08:05:050000.Dialogue: Could you grab me another napkin, sweetie?

00:08:13:070000.Speaker: Howard
00:08:13:070000.Dialogue: Inviting my girlfriend to come see your electron accelerator?

00:08:18:170000.Speaker: Howard
00:08:18:170000.Dialogue: Wow! You really are a piece of work.

00:08:23:120000.Speaker: Howard
00:08:23:120000.Dialogue: It's not enough you get the prom queen, you have to get the head of the decorating committee, too?

00:08:30:180000.Speaker: Howard
00:08:30:180000.Dialogue: Don't play innocent with me. I practically invented using fancy lab equipment to seduce women.

00:08:39:060000.Speaker: Howard
00:08:39:060000.Dialogue: Not so far, but that's not the point!

00:08:41:150000.Speaker: Leonard
00:08:41:150000.Dialogue: Howard, relax. I'm not interested in your girlfriend.

00:08:45:130000.Speaker: Howard
00:08:45:130000.Dialogue: I hope not. Because you don't want to mess with me.

00:09:02:100000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:09:02:100000.Dialogue: Research journal, entry one. I'm about to embark on one of the great challenges of my scientific career: teaching Penny physics.

00:09:20:190000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:09:20:190000.Dialogue: Come in. Take a seat. Subject has arrived. I've extended a friendly casual greeting.

00:09:36:130000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:09:36:130000.Dialogue: Subject appears well-rested and enthusiastic. Apparently, ignorance is bliss.

00:09:45:080000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:09:45:080000.Dialogue: All right, let us begin. Where's your notebook?

00:09:52:110000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:09:52:110000.Dialogue: How are you going to take notes without a notebook?

00:09:56:210000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:09:56:210000.Dialogue: How else are you gonna study for the tests?

00:10:04:220000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:10:04:220000.Dialogue: Here. It's college-ruled. I hope that's not too intimidating.

00:10:13:100000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:10:13:100000.Dialogue: You're welcome. Now, Introduction to Physics. What is physics? Physics comes from the ancient Greek word "physika. " It's at this point that you'll want to start taking notes.

00:10:29:190000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:10:29:190000.Dialogue: "Physika" means the science of natural things. And it is there, in ancient Greece, that our story begins.

00:10:42:010000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:10:42:010000.Dialogue: It's a warm summer evening, circa 600 BC. You've finished your shopping at the local market, or agora...

00:10:53:050000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:10:53:050000.Dialogue: ...and you look up at the night sky. There you notice some of the stars seem to move, so you name them "planetes," or "wanderer. "

00:11:11:000000.Speaker: Penny
00:11:11:000000.Dialogue: Um, does this have anything to do with Leonard's work?

00:11:14:060000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:11:14:060000.Dialogue: This is the beginning of a 2,600-year journey we're going to take together from the ancient Greeks through Isaac Newton to Niels Bohr to Erwin Schrodinger to the Dutch researchers that Leonard is currently ripping off.

00:11:33:100000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:11:33:100000.Dialogue: Yeah, give or take. As I was saying, it's a warm summer evening in ancient Greece... Yes, Penny?

00:11:40:100000.Speaker: Penny
00:11:40:100000.Dialogue: I have to go to the bathroom.

00:11:55:100000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:11:55:100000.Dialogue: Project Gorilla, entry two. I am exhausted.

00:12:17:040000.Speaker: Bernadette
00:12:17:040000.Dialogue: Howard? Huh? It unhooks in the front.

00:12:33:100000.Speaker: Howard’s Mother
00:12:33:100000.Dialogue: Senior fitness was cancelled. It turns out you can forget how to ride a bike.

00:12:39:070000.Speaker: Howard’s Mother
00:12:39:070000.Dialogue: I'm fine, but, oy, did Sam Harpootian eat gravel.

00:12:47:110000.Speaker: Howard’s Mother
00:12:47:110000.Dialogue: What's great about an 80-year-old Armenian man with half his chin scraped off?!

00:12:54:130000.Speaker: Howard
00:12:54:130000.Dialogue: No, no, don't move. Hey, Ma, can I have lamb stew for dinner?

00:12:59:000000.Speaker: Howard’s Mother
00:12:59:000000.Dialogue: Lamb stew? I'd have to go to the supermarket.

00:13:02:110000.Speaker: Howard
00:13:02:110000.Dialogue: Please? I got a real hankering.

00:13:08:010000.Speaker: Howard’s Mother
00:13:08:010000.Dialogue: Oh, I can't say no to my little tushy face.

00:13:19:020000.Speaker: Howard’s Mother
00:13:19:020000.Dialogue: Do you want the regular peas or the Le Seur?

00:13:22:070000.Speaker: Howard
00:13:22:070000.Dialogue: Always Le Seur peas with lamb stew!

00:13:25:150000.Speaker: Howard’s Mother
00:13:25:150000.Dialogue: You're right! When you're right, you're right!

00:13:30:220000.Speaker: Howard’s Mother
00:13:30:220000.Dialogue: What if they're out of the Le Seur?

00:13:34:220000.Speaker: Howard’s Mother
00:13:34:220000.Dialogue: All right! You don't have to yell!

00:13:43:130000.Speaker: Bernadette
00:13:43:130000.Dialogue: Let me just put that on vibrate.

00:13:49:180000.Speaker: Bernadette
00:13:49:180000.Dialogue: You know, that one I got.

00:13:53:020000.Speaker: Bernadette
00:13:53:020000.Dialogue: Howard, did you say something to Leonard about me?

00:13:56:220000.Speaker: Bernadette
00:13:56:220000.Dialogue: He says if I go see his experiment tomorrow it might weird you out.

00:14:02:130000.Speaker: Bernadette
00:14:02:130000.Dialogue: You're not jealous of Leonard, are you?

00:14:04:130000.Speaker: Howard
00:14:04:130000.Dialogue: Me? No. I may have mentioned that it's a little inappropriate to be asking another man's girlfriend to his experiment without first discussing it with said man.

00:14:15:140000.Speaker: Bernadette
00:14:15:140000.Dialogue: Are you saying I need to ask your permission to hang out with Leonard?

00:14:18:010000.Speaker: Howard
00:14:18:010000.Dialogue: I didn't say anything like that. I said Leonard has to ask my permission.

00:14:26:070000.Speaker: Howard
00:14:26:070000.Dialogue: Come on, I don't want to eat lamb stew with my mother. Damn, I was this close on the bra.

00:14:35:140000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:14:35:140000.Dialogue: Now, remember, Newton realized that Aristotle was wrong and force was not necessary to maintain motion. So let's plug in our 9.8 meters per second squared as "A" and we get force- Earth gravity- equals mass times 9.8 meters per second per second. So we can see that "ma" equals "mg" and what do we know from this?

00:15:00:230000.Speaker: Penny
00:15:00:230000.Dialogue: Uh, we know that... ...Newton was a really smart cookie.

00:15:08:010000.Speaker: Penny
00:15:08:010000.Dialogue: Oh! Is that where Fig Newtons come from?

00:15:11:020000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:15:11:020000.Dialogue: No, Fig Newtons are named after a small town in Massachusetts. Don't write that down!

00:15:18:190000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:15:18:190000.Dialogue: Now, if "ma" equals "mg," what does that imply?

00:15:23:130000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:15:23:130000.Dialogue: How can you not know? I just told you. Have you suffered a recent blow to the head?

00:15:29:050000.Speaker: Penny
00:15:29:050000.Dialogue: Hey! You don't have to be so mean!

00:15:32:030000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:15:32:030000.Dialogue: I'm sorry. Have you suffered a recent blow to the head?

00:15:38:150000.Speaker: Penny
00:15:38:150000.Dialogue: No, you just suck at teaching. Really?

00:15:41:050000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:15:41:050000.Dialogue: Of those two explanations, which one seems the most likely?

00:15:43:220000.Speaker: Penny
00:15:43:220000.Dialogue: Oh, God... Sheldon, I'm trying to understand, but you're going too fast. Can you just back up a little bit?

00:15:51:070000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:15:51:070000.Dialogue: All right. It's a warm summer evening in ancient Greece...

00:15:58:200000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:15:58:200000.Dialogue: Okay! At what point did you begin to feel lost?

00:16:02:130000.Speaker: Penny
00:16:02:130000.Dialogue: I don't know. Where were we looking up at the night sky?

00:16:07:230000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:16:07:230000.Dialogue: There's no need to get frustrated. People learn at different rates. Unlike objects falling in a vacuum, which...?

00:16:42:060000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:16:42:060000.Dialogue: One cries because one is sad. For example, I cry because others are stupid and it makes me sad.

00:16:48:050000.Speaker: Penny
00:16:48:050000.Dialogue: Okay, look, can we just please forget about all this extra stuff and can you just tell me what Leonard does?

00:16:55:130000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:16:55:130000.Dialogue: All right. Leonard is attempting to learn why sub-atomic particles move the way they do.

00:17:02:060000.Speaker: Penny
00:17:02:060000.Dialogue: Really? That's it? Well, that doesn't sound so complicated.

00:17:06:200000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:17:06:200000.Dialogue: It's not. That's why Leonard does it.

00:17:11:170000.Speaker: Penny
00:17:11:170000.Dialogue: Okay, I just have one question. What exactly are sub-atomic particles?

00:17:20:160000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:17:20:160000.Dialogue: And to answer it, we first must ask ourselves: "What is physics?"

00:17:25:030000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:17:25:030000.Dialogue: It's a warm summer evening in ancient Greece...

00:17:29:220000.Speaker: Howard
00:17:29:220000.Dialogue: Okay, I got a bone to pick with you.

00:17:34:010000.Speaker: Howard
00:17:34:010000.Dialogue: I was in bed with Bernadette, and you text-blocked me.

00:17:39:200000.Speaker: Howard
00:17:39:200000.Dialogue: We were completely naked, about to devour each other when,

00:17:44:040000.Speaker: Howard
00:17:44:040000.Dialogue: you text her that I have a problem with her hanging out with you.

00:17:47:040000.Speaker: Leonard
00:17:47:040000.Dialogue: You do have a problem with her hanging out with me.

00:17:50:110000.Speaker: Howard
00:17:50:110000.Dialogue: Yeah, but that's not what you tell her.

00:17:52:100000.Speaker: Leonard
00:17:52:100000.Dialogue: What was I supposed to tell her?

00:17:54:010000.Speaker: Howard
00:17:54:010000.Dialogue: I don't know; something that doesn't make me come off as a petty, jealous douche.

00:18:03:160000.Speaker: Howard
00:18:03:160000.Dialogue: Come on, do I have to think of everything?

00:18:07:000000.Speaker: Bernadette
00:18:07:000000.Dialogue: Hey, Leonard. Am I too late to see the experiment? Oh, hi.

00:18:13:160000.Speaker: Howard
00:18:13:160000.Dialogue: Same thing you're doing here. I came to see Leonard's experiment.

00:18:17:160000.Speaker: Bernadette
00:18:17:160000.Dialogue: No, you didn't. You said Leonard's experiment was stupid.

00:18:24:150000.Speaker: Leonard
00:18:24:150000.Dialogue: You told her my experiment was stupid?

00:18:27:030000.Speaker: Howard
00:18:27:030000.Dialogue: I was just repeating what Sheldon said.

00:18:30:110000.Speaker: Howard
00:18:30:110000.Dialogue: Let's not get off topic. Bernadette, I need to apologize. I was wrong to tell you who you should be friends with.

00:18:38:110000.Speaker: Leonard
00:18:38:110000.Dialogue: Should I, um, leave you two alone?

00:18:40:200000.Speaker: Bernadette
00:18:40:200000.Dialogue: No, Leonard, you should hear this.

00:18:42:080000.Speaker: Leonard
00:18:42:080000.Dialogue: Okay, good, 'cause I wasn't really gonna go.

00:18:45:070000.Speaker: Howard
00:18:45:070000.Dialogue: Look, I know I come off as confident and worldly, but...

00:18:56:210000.Speaker: Howard
00:18:56:210000.Dialogue: Which is why I tend to feel threatened by other guys.

00:19:02:010000.Speaker: Leonard
00:19:02:010000.Dialogue: Or loud noises, clowns and nuns.

00:19:07:120000.Speaker: Howard
00:19:07:120000.Dialogue: But I now realize how foolish that is.

00:19:10:130000.Speaker: Leonard
00:19:10:130000.Dialogue: He had a panic attack once when he got his head stuck in a sweater.

00:19:15:080000.Speaker: Howard
00:19:15:080000.Dialogue: It was a full turtleneck. Why aren't you helping me?

00:19:19:140000.Speaker: Leonard
00:19:19:140000.Dialogue: I don't know. Maybe because I'm... crazy?!

00:19:28:060000.Speaker: Howard
00:19:28:060000.Dialogue: Bernadette, please, I'm asking you to give me another chance.

00:19:31:130000.Speaker: Bernadette
00:19:31:130000.Dialogue: What do you think, Leonard? Should I give him another chance?

00:19:35:060000.Speaker: Leonard
00:19:35:060000.Dialogue: It's up to you. He didn't call your experiment stupid.

00:19:53:000000.Speaker: Bernadette
00:19:53:000000.Dialogue: Raj, you should've seen Leonard's experiment. The interference pattern was so cool when the electron beam was on.

00:19:59:040000.Speaker: Leonard
00:19:59:040000.Dialogue: Glad you enjoyed it. Most people aren't that interested in what I do.

00:20:09:160000.Speaker: Penny
00:20:09:160000.Dialogue: Actually, that's not true, Leonard. In fact, recently I've been thinking that given the parameters of your experiment, the transport of electrons through the aperture of the nano-fabricated metal rings is qualitatively no different than the experiment already conducted in the Netherlands.

00:20:25:140000.Speaker: Penny
00:20:25:140000.Dialogue: Their observed phase shift in the diffusing electrons inside the metal ring already conclusively demonstrated the electric analogue of the Aharonov-Bohm quantum-interference effect.

00:20:39:120000.Speaker: Penny
00:20:39:120000.Dialogue: That's it. That's all I know.

00:20:42:210000.Speaker: Penny
00:20:42:210000.Dialogue: Oh, wait...! Fig Newtons were named after a town in Massachusetts, not the scientist.
